tit.cmt: 直後に記述があるので(a roofing method)は削除しました。

sen.j: 杮葺（こけらぶき）とは、屋根葺手法の一つで、木材の薄板を用いて施工する。
sen.e: Kokerabuki is a roofing method in which thin wood boards are used as the roof materials.
Kokerabuki is a roofing method in which thin wood boards are used as the roofing material.
Kokerabuki is a roofing method in which thin wood boards are used as the roofing material.

sen.j: 板葺（いたぶき）の代名詞にも使われる。
sen.e: It was also used for indicating Itabuki (roofing using boards)
It was also used to refer to Itabuki (roofing using boards).
It is also used to refer to Itabuki (shingle roofing).
sen.cmt: 用語集に統一。原稿にしたがって現在形にしました。

sen.j: 日本古来から伝わる伝統的手法で、多くの文化財の屋根で見ることができる。
sen.e: It is a traditional roofing method used from ancient times in Japan, and are used for the roofs of many cultural properties.
It is a traditional roofing method used from ancient times in Japan, and is used for the roofs of many cultural properties.
It is a traditional roofing method used from ancient times in Japan, and is used for the roofs of many cultural properties.

sen.j: 広義では板葺の一種であり、板葺は板の厚さにより以下の種類がある。
sen.e: In the broader sense, it is a kind of Itabuki, and Itabuki includes the following types depending on the thickness of the boards used:
In a broader sense, it is a kind of Itabuki, and Itabuki includes the following types depending on the thickness of the boards used:
In a broader sense, it is a kind of Itabuki, and Itabuki includes the following types depending on the thickness of the boards used:

sen.j: 杮葺（こけらぶき）
sen.e: Kokerabuki
Kokerabuki
Kokerabuki

sen.j: 最も薄い板（杮板）を用いる。
sen.e: Thinnest boards (kokera boards) are used.
Thinnest boards (kokera boards) are used.
Thinnest boards (kokera boards) are used.

sen.j: 板厚は2～3ミリメートル。
sen.e: The thickness is two to three millimeters.
The thickness is two to three millimeters.
The thickness is two to three millimeters.

sen.j: 木賊葺（とくさぶき）
sen.e: Tokusabuki
Tokusabuki
Tokusabuki

sen.j: 杮板よりも厚い板（木賊板）を用いる。
sen.e: Boards thicker than kokera boards are used.
Boards thicker than kokera boards are used.
Boards thicker than kokera boards are used.

sen.j: 板厚は4～7ミリメートル。
sen.e: The thickness is four to seven millimeters.
The thickness is four to seven millimeters.
The thickness is four to seven millimeters.

sen.j: 栩葺（とちぶき）
sen.e: Tochi(栩)buki
Tochibuki
Tochibuki

sen.j: 最も厚い板（栩板）を用いる。
sen.e: Thickest boards (tochi boards) are used.
Thickest boards (tochi boards) are used.
Thickest boards (tochi boards) are used.

sen.j: 板厚は1～3センチメートル。
sen.e: The thickness is one to three centimeters.
The thickness is one to three centimeters.
The thickness is one to three centimeters.

sen.j: 法隆寺金堂の裳階だけに見られる厚い木片を互い違いに重ねた板屋根が用いられている。
sen.e: The mokoshi (small roof-like structures attached to walls) unique to the main hall of Horyu-ji Temple is provided with the roofs made by placing a board overlapping the adjacent board..
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The mokoshi (small roof-like structures attached to walls), unique to the main hall of Horyu-ji Temple, have roofs made by placing a board overlapping the adjacent board.
The mokoshi (small roof-like structures attached to walls), unique to the main hall of Horyu-ji Temple, have roofs made by placing a board overlapping the adjacent board.

sen.j: この屋根は、大和葺（やまとぶき）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The roof of this type is called a Yamatobuki roof.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The roof of this type is called a Yamatobuki roof.
The roof of this type is called a Yamatobuki roof.

sen.j: 尚、「杮（こけら）」の字と「柿（かき）」の字は非常に似ているが別字である。
sen.e: By the way, the shape of the character "杮" (kokera) and that of the character "柿" (persimmon) are quite similar but different.
It should be noted that the shape of the character "杮" (kokera) and that of the character "柿" (persimmon) are quite similar but different.
sen.cmt: “by the way” is too conversational for this context
sen.e: It should be noted that the shape of the character "杮" (kokera) and that of the character "柿" (persimmon) are quite similar but different.

sen.j: 「杮（こけら）」は「こけらおとし」の「こけら」同様、木片・木屑の意味。
sen.e: "杮" (kokera) indicates a piece of wood or wood shavings as in "kokera" in "kokera-otoshi" (literally, making kokera drop and actually, meaning the opening of a new theater: this term originates in that pieces of unnecessary wood are dropped after the building work completed).

"杮" (kokera) indicates a piece of wood or wood shavings as in "kokera" in "kokera-otoshi" (literally, dropping kokera and actually, meaning the opening of a new theater: this term originates in that pieces of unnecessary wood are dropped after the building work completed).

"杮" (kokera) indicates a piece of wood or wood shavings as in "kokera" in "kokera-otoshi" (literally, dropping kokera and actually, meaning the opening of a new theater: this term originates in that pieces of unnecessary wood are dropped after the building work completed).

sen.j: ただし、両者は混用された（記事「こけら落し」に詳しい）。
sen.e: However, use of them has been mixed (for more information, refer to "Kokera-otoshi).
However, use of these terms has been mixed (for more information, refer to "Kokera-otoshi).
However, use of these terms has been mixed (for more information, refer to "Kokera-otoshi").

sen.j: 材料
sen.e: Materials
Materials
Materials

sen.j: ヒノキ、サワラ (植物)、スギ、エノキなど、筋目がよく通って削ぎやすく、水に強い材木が用いられる。
sen.e: Clear-striped water-resistant and scraped-easily wood, such as (Japanese) cypress, Japanese falsecypress, Japanese cedar and Japanese hackberry, is used.
Water-resistant wood with a pronounced grain that is easy to shape, such as Japanese cypress, Japanese false cypress, Japanese cedar and Japanese hackberry, is used.
sen.cmt: that first part didn't make much sense as it was
sen.e: Water-resistant wood with a pronounced grain that is easy to shape, such as Japanese cypress, Japanese false cypress, Japanese cedar and Japanese hackberry, is used.

sen.j: クヌギ（栩）やトクサ（木賊）が材料ではない。
sen.e: Kunugi (sawtooth oak) （栩） and tokusa are not such materials.
Kunugi (sawtooth oak) and tokusa are not such materials.
Kunugi (sawtooth oak) and tokusa are not such materials.

sen.j: 板は年輪に沿って割られたものが用いられる。
sen.e: The boards obtained by cutting woods along their growth ring are used.
The boards used are made by cutting wood along the growth rings.
The boards used are made by cutting wood along the growth rings.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 板葺の歴史は茅葺に次いで古い。
sen.e: The history of itabuki is older next to that of kayabuski (thatched roofs).
The history of itabuki is old, second only to that of kayabuski (thatched roofs).
sen.cmt: the comparative “older” and the phrase “next to” have conflicting meanings
sen.e: The history of itabuki is old, second only to that of kayabuski (thatched roofs).

sen.j: 法隆寺五重塔の屋根にも使用されていることから、古墳時代から屋根材として使用されはじめたと思われる。
sen.e: Itabuki is used for the roofs of the five-storied pagoda in Horyu-ji Temple, and therefore, it is considered that use of boards for roofs started in the Kofun period (tumulus period).
Itabuki is used for the roofs of the five-storied pagoda in Horyu-ji Temple, and therefore it is thought that use of boards for roofs started in the Kofun period.
sen.cmt: I don't think “tumulus” means much to the average reader
sen.e: Itabuki is used for the roofs of the five-storied pagoda in Horyu-ji Temple, and therefore it is thought that use of boards for roofs started in the Kofun period.

sen.j: 以後、道具の進化もあり、より薄い板を用いる手法が開発され、最も薄い板を用いる杮葺は平安時代初期には使用されはじめる。
sen.e: After that, with the tools concerned progressed, methods of using thinner boards had been developed, and use of korerabuki, utilizing the thinnest boards, started in the early Heian period.
Later on, as tools improved, methods for using thinner boards were developed, and use of korerabuki, utilizing the thinnest boards, started in the early Heian period.
Later on, as tools improved, methods for using thinner boards were developed, and use of kokerabuki, utilizing the thinnest boards, started in the early Heian period.

sen.j: 江戸時代までは栩葺・木賊葺も社寺建築に使用されていた。
sen.e: Until the Edo period, tochibuki and tokusabuki had also been used in shrine buildings and in temple buildings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Until the Edo period, tochibuki and tokusabuki had also been used in shrine buildings and in temple buildings.
Until the Edo period, tochibuki and tokusabuki had also been used in shrine buildings and in temple buildings.

sen.j: しかし、板が厚く直線に近い屋根しか葺くことができない。
sen.e: However, because thicker boards are used in these methods, only roofs with nearly straight lines were able to be provided.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, because thicker boards are used in these methods, they only worked on roofs with nearly straight lines.
sen.cmt: “provided” really is not that versatile a word
sen.e: However, because thicker boards are used in these methods, they only worked on roofs with nearly straight lines.

sen.j: このため、薄板で自在性が高い杮葺へと次第に移っていった。
sen.e: Therefore, the kokerabuki that, with use of thinner boards, is provided with high flexibility has become more widely used gradually.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, kokerabuki with thinner, flexible boards has gradually become more widely used.
Therefore, kokerabuki with thinner, flexible boards has gradually become more widely used.

sen.j: 三仏寺本堂のように、建立当時は栩葺や木賊葺であったが後世の修復で杮葺へ変わった建築物も数多い。
sen.e: There are many buildings, including Hondo Hall of Sanbutsu-ji Temple, in which tochibuki or tokusabuki was initially used for their roofs but was replaced with kokerabucki later.
There are many buildings, including Hondo Hall of Sanbutsu-ji Temple, in which tochibuki or tokusabuki was initially used for the roof but was replaced with kokerabucki later.
There are many buildings, including Hondo Hall of Sanbutsu-ji Temple, in which tochibuki or tokusabuki was initially used for the roof but was replaced with kokerabuki later.

sen.j: よって、現存する板葺の文化財は多くが杮葺で、栩葺・木賊葺は少なく屋根職人も殆どいない。
sen.e: Therefore, of the still existing cultural properties with itabuki roofs, most use kokerabushi.
Therefore, most extant cultural properties with itabuki roofs use kokerabushi.
Therefore, most extant cultural properties with itabuki roofs use kokerabuki, and few of them use tochibuki or tokusabuki, so it is hard to find craftsmen who can work on these methods.
sen.cmt: スペルミス修正「訳漏れ対応しました」

sen.j: 葺きかた
sen.e: Roofing methods
Roofing methods
Roofing methods

sen.j: 板葺に共通で、幅9～10センチメートル、長さ24～30センチメートルの板が用いられる。
sen.e: For itabuki roofs, 9 - 10 cm wide and 24 - 30 cm long boards are used commonly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Itabuki roofs commonly use boards 9-10cm wide and 24-30cm long.
Itabuki roofs commonly use boards 9-10cm wide and 24-30cm long.

sen.j: これらの板をずらしながら下から平行に重ねて並べ、竹釘で止める。
sen.e: These boards are placed horizontally so that a board overlaps the adjacent board, and are fixed with bamboo pegs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These boards are placed horizontally so that a board overlaps the adjacent board, and are fixed with bamboo pegs.
These boards are placed horizontally so that a board overlaps the adjacent board, and are fixed with bamboo pegs.

sen.j: 木材を横に渡し、石で固定するだけの場合もある。
sen.e: Sometimes, logs are placed over these boards horizontally, and only stones are used for fixing them.
Sometimes, logs are placed over these boards horizontally, and only stones are used for holding them in place.
Sometimes, logs are placed over these boards horizontally, and only stones are used for holding them in place.

sen.j: 板の間に少しの隙間が生じ、これが軒裏の通気を促して木材の耐久性を向上させる。
sen.e: Small gaps are generated between these boards, generating air flow from the area under the ridge and therefore, increasing the durability of the wood materials.
Small gaps are made between these boards, generating air flow from the area under the ridge, and thereby increasing the durability of the wood.
Small gaps are made between these boards, generating air flow from the area under the ridge, and thereby increasing the durability of the wood.

sen.j: 杮葺きは通常40年程度の耐久性があるといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that korerabuski roofs ordinarily provides a life of around 40 years.
It is said that korerabuski roofs ordinarily have a life of around 40 years.
It is said that kokerabuki roofs ordinarily have a life of around 40 years.

sen.j: しかし近年は板製造作業の機械化により木の繊維がせん断されてしまう。
sen.e: However, the work to make boards has been mechanized recently, making the fiber of wood cut
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, board making has been mechanized recently, resulting in cutting of the wood fiber.
However, board making has been mechanized recently, resulting in cutting of the wood fiber.

sen.j: したがって、手作業の板よりも耐用年数が劣る。
sen.e: Therefore, the lives of the roofs using these boards have become shorter than those using manually prepared boards.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the lifespan of roofs made with these boards is shorter than that of those made with hand-made boards.
Therefore, the lifespan of roofs made with these boards is shorter than that of those made with hand-made boards.

sen.j: そのため、下地の防水処理や、材木自体の防腐処理を施している。
sen.e: Fore this reason, nowadays, waterproofing treatment is given to the surfaces of these boards or preservative treatment is given と these boards themselves.
Fore this reason, nowadays, waterproofing treatment is given to the surfaces of these boards or preservative treatment is given to the boards themselves.
sen.cmt: english “to” got turned into a hiragana とplease read over your work once before sending it out
sen.e: Fore this reason, nowadays, waterproofing treatment is given to the surfaces of these boards or preservative treatment is given to the boards themselves.

The main hall of Sanbutsu-ji Temple (tokusabuki was used when the hall was built initially, and kokerabuski is used now).
The main hall of Sanbutsu-ji Temple (tokusabuki was used when the hall was built initially, and kokerabuki is used now).

sen.e: The Emadokoro (a hall where special plates for prayer are placed) of Kitano Tenman-gu Shrine (tokusabuki was used when the hall was build initially: a tiled roof is used now.)
